castItem.roleDesc: a young Athenian, friend of Philolaches

stage.#text: Scene--; before the houses of THEUROPIDES and SIMO.

p.#text: WHILE Theuropides is absent from home on business, his son Philolaches leads a dissolute life at home with his friend Callidamates and his own servant Tranio While they are in the midst of their carousals, the father of Philolaches unexpectedly arrives at . Their first impulse is to leave the house immediately, but, Callidamates being in a state of helpless intoxication, they are prevented from so doing. In this dilemma, Tranio undertakes to rescue them. He requests them to remain perfectly quiet in the house, and not to stir out of it. The house is then shut up, and he sallies forth to meet Theuropides. He pretends to him that the house has been shut up for some months past, in consequence of its being haunted. In the midst of the conversation, he is accosted by a Banker, who duns him for the interest of some money which Philolaches has borrowed of him for the purpose of procuring the freedom of Philematium, his mistress. Theuropides enquires what the money was borrowed for, on which Tranio says that Philolaches has purchased a house with it. On Theuropides making further enquiries, Tranio says that he has bought the house in which Simo is living. On this, Theuropides wishes to examine this new purchase, and sends Tranio to request Simo to allow him to do so, if not inconvenient. Tranio obtains the permission, Simo being ignorant of the object, and they go over the house, Theuropides being much pleased with his son's bargain. Tranio is then sent by Theuropides into the country to fetch Philolaches thence, he having pretended that he is there. Shortly after, a servant of Callidamates comes to the house that is shut up to fetch his master home. Theuropides questions him, and then finds out the deception that has been practised upon him; and on receiving further information from Simo, who declares that he has not sold his own house, he resolves to punish Tranio. The latter, on finding this to be the case, runs to an altar for refuge. Callidamates, who is now sober, and has got out of the house by the back-gate, now makes his appearance, and, at his earnest intercession, pardon is granted by Theuropides to Philolaches and Tranio.

note.#text: Title :  This is a word probably derived from "mostellum," the diminutive of "monstrum," a "spectre" or "prodigy." It was probably coined by Plautus to serve as the title of this Play, which is called by several of the ancient Commentators by the name of "Phasma," "the Apparition."

stage.#text: Enter, from the house of THEUROPIDES, GRUMIO, pushing out TRANIO.

sp.speaker: GRUMIO
sp.p: Get out of the kitchen, will you; out of it, you whip-scoundrel, who are giving me your cavilling talk amid the platters; march out of the house, you ruin of your master. Upon my faith, if I only live, I'll be soundly revenged upon you in the country. Get out, I say, you steam of the kitchen. Why are you skulking thus?

note.#text: :  Grumio appears to have been cook and herdsman combined, and perhaps generally employed at the country farm of Theuropides. On this occasion he seems to have been summoned to town to cook for the entertainment which Philolaches is giving to his friends.

p.#text: Why the plague are you making this noise here before the house? Do you fancy yourself to be in the country? Get out of the house; be off into the country. Go and hang yourself. Get away from the door.  There now, was it that you wanted?
. I'm undone! Why are you beating me? TRA. Because you want it.

sp.speaker: GRUMIO
sp.p: I must endure it. Only let the old gentleman return home; only let him come safe home, whom you are devouring in his absence.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: You don't say what's either likely or true, you blockhead, as to any one devouring a person in his absence.

note.#text: :  The gang of slaves, who, for their malpractices, are working in the country in chains.

:  "Pergrcamini." Though the Scene is at , Plautus consults the taste of a Roman Audience, as on many other occasions, in making the Greeks the patterns of riotous livers. Asconius Pedianus says that at these entertainments the Greeks drank off a cup of wine every tune they named a Divinity or mentioned a friend.

p.#text: Indeed, you town wit, you minion of the mob, do you throw the country in my teeth? Really, Tranio, I do believe that you feel sure that before long you'll be handed over to the mill. Within a short period, i' faith, Tranio, you'll full soon be adding to the iron-bound race in the country. While you choose to, and have the opportunity, drink on, squander his property, corrupt my master's son, a most worthy young man, drink night and day, live like Greeks, make purchase of mistresses, give them their freedom, feed parasites, feast yourselves sumptuously. Was it thus that the old gentleman enjoined you when he went hence abroad? Is it after this fashion that he will find his property well husbanded? Do you suppose that this is the duty of a good servant, to be ruining both the estate and the son of his master? For I do consider him as ruined, when he devotes himself to these goings on. A person, with whom not one of all the young men of  was before deemed equally frugal or more steady, the same is now carrying off the palm in the opposite direction. Through your management and your tutoring has that been done.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: What the plague business have you with me or with what I do? Prithee, haven't you got your cattle in the country for you to look to? I choose to drink, to intrigue, to keep my wenches; this I do at the peril of my own back, and not of yours

p.#text: Then with what assurance he does talk!  Faugh!
But may  and all the Deities confound you; you stink of garlick, you filth unmistakeable, you clod, you he-goat, you pig-sty, you mixture of dog and she-goat.

sp.speaker: GRUMIO
sp.p: What would you have to be done? It isn't all that can smell of foreign perfumes, if you smell of them; or that can take their places at table above their master, or live on such exquisite dainties as you live upon. Do you keep to yourself those turtle-doves, that fish, and poultry; let me enjoy my lot upon garlick diet. You are fortunate; I unlucky. It must be endured. Let my good fortune be awaiting me, your bad yourself.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: You seem, Grumio, as though you envied me, because I enjoy myself and you are wretched. It is quite my due. It's proper for me to make love, and for you to feed the cattle; for me to fare handsomely, you in a miserable way.

note.#text: :  Riddled with holes by the scourge of the executioner.
:  Bearing his own cross; a refinement of torture which was too often employed upon malefactors.

p.#text: O riddle for the executioner, as I guess it will turn out; they'll be so pinking you with goads, as you carry your gibbet along the streets one day, as soon as ever the old gentleman returns here.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: How do you know whether that mayn't happen to yourself sooner than to me?

sp.speaker: GRUMIO
sp.p: Because I have never deserved it; you have deserved it, and you now deserve it.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Do cut short the trouble of your talking, unless you wish a heavy mischance to befall you.

sp.speaker: GRUMIO
sp.p: Are you going to give me the tares for me to take for the cattle? If you are not, give me the money. Go on, still persist in the way in which you've commenced! Drink, live like Greeks, eat, stuff yourselves, slaughter your fatlings!

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Hold your tongue, and be off into the country; I intend to go to the Pirus to get me some fish for the evening. To-morrow I'll make some one bring you the tares to the farm. What's the matter? Why now are you staring at me, gallows-bird?

sp.speaker: GRUMIO
sp.p: I' faith, I've an idea that will be your own title before long.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: So long as it is as it is, in the meantime I'll put up with that "before long."

sp.speaker: GRUMIO
sp.p: That's the way; and understand this one thing, that that which is disagreable comes much more speedily than that which you wish for.

p.#text: Don't you be annoying; now then, away with you into the country, and betake yourself off. Don't you deceive yourself, henceforth you shan't be causing me any impediment.

. Is he really gone? Not to care one straw for what I've said! O immortal Gods, I do implore your aid, do cause this old gentleman of ours, who has now been three years absent from here, to return hither as soon as possible, before everything is gone, both house and land. Unless he does return here, remnants to last for a few months only are left. Now I'll be off to the country; but look! I see my master's son, one who has been corrupted from having been a most excellent young man.

div2.stage: Enter PHILOLACHES, from the house of THEUROPIDES.

note.#text: :  From this passage it would seem that pains were taken to give the houses a smooth and polished appearance on the outside.

:  Warner remarks that a sentiment not unlike this is found in Scripture, Ecclesiastes, x. 18: "By much slothfulness the building decayeth; and through idleness of the hands the house droppeth through." It may be also observed that the passage is very similar to the words of the parable of the foolish man who built his house upon sand, St. Matthew, vii. 26: "And the rain descended, and the floods came, and the winds blew and beat upon that house, and it fell; and great was the fall thereof."
:  In the first year of military service the Roman youths were placed under the tutelage of some relation or friend.
:  "Arte gymnastic." Literally, "in the gymnastic art."
:  "Victitabam volup." Lambinus suggests that the true reading here is "haud volup," "not voluptuously."

p.#text: . I've often thought and long reflected on it, and in my breast have held many a debate, and in my heart (if any heart I have) have revolved this matter, and long discussed it, to what thing I'm to consider man as like, and what form he has when he is born? I've now discovered this likeness. I think a man is like unto a new house when he is born. I'll give my proofs of this fact.  And does not this seem to you like the truth? But so I'll manage that you shall think it is so. Beyond a doubt I'll convince you that it is true what I say. And this yourselves, I'm sure, when you have heard my words, will say is no otherwise than just as I now affirm that it is. Listen while I repeat my proofs of this fact; I want you to be equally knowing with myself upon this matter. As soon as ever a house is built up, nicely polished off, carefully erected, and according to rule, people praise the architect and approve of the house, they take from it each one a model for himself. Each one has something similar, quite at his own expense; they do not spare their pains. But when a worthless, lazy, dirty, negligent fellow betakes himself thither with an idle family, then is it imputed as a fault to the house, while a good house is being kept in bad repair. And this is often the case; a storm comes on and breaks the tiles and gutters; then a careless owner takes no heed to put up others. A shower comes on and streams down the walls; the rafters admit the rain; the weather rots the labours of the builder; then the utility of the house becomes diminished; and yet this is not the fault of the builder. But a great part of mankind have contracted this habit of delay; if anything can be repaired by means of money, they are always still putting it off, and don't * * * do it until the walls come tumbling down; then the whole house has to be built anew. These instances from buildings I've mentioned; and now I wish to inform you how you are to suppose that men are like houses. In the first place then, the parents are the builders-up of the children, and lay the foundation for the children; they raise them up, they carefully train them to strength, and that they may be good both for service and for view before the public. They spare not either their own pains or their cost, nor do they deem expense in that to be an expense. They refine them, teach them literature, the ordinances, the laws; at their own cost and labour they struggle, that others may wish for their own children to be like to them. When they repair to the army, they then find them some relation of theirs as a protector. At that moment they pass out of the builder's hands. One year's pay has now been earned; at that period, then, a sample is on view how the building will turn out. But I was always discreet and virtuous, just as long as I was under the management of the builder. After I had left him to follow the bent of my own inclinations, at once I entirely spoiled the labours of the builders. Idleness came on; that was my storm; on its arrival, upon me it brought down hail and showers, which overthrew my modesty and the bounds of virtue, and untiled them for me in an instant. After that I was neglectful to cover in again; at once passion like a torrent entered my heart; it flowed down even unto my breast, and soaked through my heart. Now both property, credit, fair fame, virtue, and honor have forsaken me; by usage have I become much worse, and, i' faith (so rotten are these rafters of mine with moisture), I do not seem to myself to be able possibly to patch up my house to prevent it from falling down totally once for all, from perishing from the foundation, and from no one being able to assist me. My heart pains me, when I reflect how I now am and how I once was, than whom in youthful age not one there was more active in the arts of exercise, with the quoit, the javelin, the ball, racing, arms, and horses. I then lived a joyous life; in frugality and hardihood I was an example to others; all, even the most deserving, took a lesson from me for themselves. Now that I'm become worthless, to that, indeed, have I hastened through the bent of my inclinations.

div2.stage: Enter PHILEMATITUM and SCAPHA, with all the requisites for a toilet.

sp.speaker: PHILEMATIUM
sp.p: On my word, for this long time I've not bathed in cold water with more delight than just now; nor do I think that I ever was, my dear Scapha, more thoroughly cleansed than now.

sp.speaker: SCAPHA
sp.p: May the upshot of everything be unto you like a plenteous year's harvest.

sp.speaker: PHILEMATIUM
sp.p: What has this harvest got to do with my bathing?

sp.speaker: SCAPHA
sp.p: Not a bit more than your bathing has to do with the harvest.

p.#text: . O beauteous Venus, this is that storm of mine which stripped off all the modesty with which I was roofed; through which Desire and Cupid poured their shower into my breast; and never since have I been able to roof it in. Now are my walls soaking in my heart; this building is utterly undone.

sp.speaker: PHILEMATIUM
sp.p: Do look, my Scapha, there's a dear, whether this dress quite becomes me. I wish to please Philolaches my protector, the apple of my eye.

note.#text: :  That is, the body.

p.#text: Nay but, you set yourself off to advantage with pleasing manners, inasmuch as you yourself are pleasing. The lover isn't in love with a woman's dress, but with that which stuffs out the dress.
. So may the Gods bless me, Scapha is waggish; the hussy's quite knowing. How cleverly she understands all matters, the maxims of lovers too!

sp.speaker: PHILEMATIUM
sp.p: Well now?

sp.speaker: SCAPHA
sp.p: What is it?

sp.speaker: PHILEMATIUM
sp.p: Why look at me and examine, how this becomes me.

sp.speaker: SCAPHA
sp.p: Thanks to your good looks, it happens that whatever you put on becomes you.

p.#text: . Now then, for that expression, Scapha, I'll make you some present or other to-day, and I won't allow you to have praised her for nothing who is so pleasing to me.

sp.speaker: PHILEMATIUM
sp.p: I don't want you to flatter me.

sp.speaker: SCAPHA
sp.p: Really you are a very simple woman. Come now, would you rather be censured undeservedly, than be praised with truth? Upon my faith, for my own part, even though undeservedly, I'd much rather be praised than be found fault with with reason, or that other people should laugh at mny appearance.

sp.speaker: PHILEMATIUM
sp.p: I love the truth; I wish the truth to be told me; I detest a liar.

sp.speaker: SCAPHA
sp.p: So may you love me, and so may your Philolaches love you, how charming you are.

p.#text: . How say you, you hussy? In what words did you adjure? "So may I love her?" Why wasn't "So may she love me" added as well? I revoke the present. What I just now promised you is done for; you have lost the present.

sp.speaker: SCAPHA
sp.p: Troth, for my part I am surprised that you, a person so knowing, so clever, and so well educated, are not aware that you are acting foolishly.

sp.speaker: PHILEMATIUM
sp.p: Then give me your advice, I beg, if I have done wrong in anything.

sp.speaker: SCAPHA
sp.p: I' faith, you certainly do wrong, in setting your mind upon him alone, in fact, and humouring him in particular in this way and slighting other men. It's the part of a married woman, and not of courtesans, to be devoted to a single lover.

p.#text: . O Jupiter! Why, what pest is this that has befallen my house? May all the Gods and Goddesses destroy me in the worst of fashions, if I don't kill this old hag with thirst, and hunger, and cold.

sp.speaker: PHILEMATIUM
sp.p: I don't want you, Scapha, to be giving me bad advice.

sp.speaker: SCAPHA
sp.p: You are clearly a simpleton, in thinking that he'll for everlasting be your friend and well-wisher. I warn you of that; he'll forsake you by reason of age and satiety.

sp.speaker: PHILEMATIUM
sp.p: I hope not.

sp.speaker: SCAPHA
sp.p: Things which you don't hope happen more frequently than things which you do hope. In fine, if you cannot be persuaded by words to believe this to be the truth, judge of my words from facts; consider this instance, who I now am, and who I once was. No less than your are now, was I once beloved, and I devoted myself to one, who, faith, when with age this head changed its hue, forsook and deserted me. Depend on it, the same will happen to yourself.

p.#text: . I can scarcely withhold myself from flying at the eyes of this mischief-maker.

sp.speaker: PHILEMATIUM
sp.p: I am of opinion that I ought to keep myself alone devoted to him, since to myself alone has he given freedom for himself alone.

p.#text: . O ye immortal Gods! what a charming woman, and of a disposition how chaste! By heaven, 'tis excellently done, and I'm rejoiced at it, that it is for her sake I've got nothing left.

sp.speaker: SCAPHA
sp.p: On my word you really are silly.

sp.speaker: PHILEMATIUM
sp.p: For what reason?

sp.speaker: SCAPHA
sp.p: Because you care for this, whether he loves you.

sp.speaker: PHILEMATIUM
sp.p: Prithee, why should I not care for it?

sp.speaker: SCAPHA
sp.p: You now are free. You've now got what you wanted; if he didn't still love you, as much money as he gave for your liberty, he'd lose.

p.#text: . Heavens, I'm a dead man if I don't torture her to death after the most shocking fashion. That evil-persuading enticer to vice is corrupting this damsel.

sp.speaker: PHILOLACHES
sp.p: Scapha, I can never return him sufficient thanks for what he deserves of me; don't you be persuading me to esteem him less.

sp.speaker: SCAPHA
sp.p: But take care and reflect upon this one thing, if you devote yourself to him alone, while now you are at this youthful age, you'll be complaining to no purpose in your aged years.

p.#text: . I could wish myself this instant changed into a quinsy, that I might seize the throat of that old witch, and put an end to the wicked mischief-maker.

sp.speaker: PHILEMATIUM
sp.p: It befits me now to have the same grateful feelings since I obtained it, as formerly before I acquired it, when I used to lavish caresses upon him.

p.#text: . May the Gods do towards me what they please, if for that speech I don't make you free over again, and if I don't torture Scapha to death.

lemma.#text: Assume the character of a wife

note.#text: :  "Capiundos crines." Literally, "the hair must be assumed." Festus says that it was usual on the occasion of the marriage ceremony, to add six rows of curls to the hair of the bride, in imitation of the Vestal virgins, who were patterns of purity, and were dressed in that manner. Hence the term "capere crines" came to signify "to become a wife."

p.#text: If you are quite assured that you will have a provision to the end, and that this lover will be your own for life, I think that you ought to devote yourself to him alone, and assume the character of a wife.

sp.speaker: PHILEMATIUM
sp.p: Just as a person's character is, he's in the habit of finding means accordingly; if I keep a good character for myself I shall be rich enough.

p.#text: . By my troth, since selling there must be, my father shall be sold much sooner than, while I'm alive, I'll ever permit you to be in want or go a-begging.

sp.speaker: SCAPHA
sp.p: What's to become of the rest of those who are in love with you?

sp.speaker: PHILEMATIUM
sp.p: They'll love me the more when they see me displaying gratitude to one who has done me services.

p.#text: . I do wish that news were brought me now that my father's dead, that I might disinherit myself of my property, and that she might be my heir.

note.#text: :  "Sagina plane est." "Sagina" was the term applied to the fattening or cramming of animals for the purpose of killing. The use of the term implies Scapha's notion of the bestial kind of life that Philolaches was leading.

p.#text: This property of his will certainly soon be at an end; day and night there's eating and drinking, and no one displays thriftiness; 'tis downright cramming.
. I' faith, I'm determined to make trial on yourself for the first to be thrifty; for you shall neither eat nor drink anything at my house for the next ten days.

sp.speaker: PHILEMATIUM
sp.p: If you choose to say anything good about him, you shall be at liberty to say it; if you speak otherwise than well, on my word you shall have a beating instantly.

p.#text: . Upon my faith, if I had paid sacrifice to supreme Jove with that money which I gave for her liberty, never could I have so well employed it. Do see, how, from her very heart's core, she loves me! Oh, I'm a fortunate man; I've liberated in her a patron to plead my cause for me.

sp.speaker: SCAPHA
sp.p: I see that, compared with Philolaches, you disregard all other men; now, that on his account I mayn't get a beating, I'll agree with you in preference, if you are quite satisfied that he will always prove a friend to you.

note.#text: :  Probably a mirror with a handle, such as the servants usually held for their mistresses. There is something comical in the notion of a female coming out into the street to make her toilet.

p.#text: Give me the mirror, and the casket with my trinkets, directly, Scapha, that I may be quite dressed when Philolaches, my delight, comes here.

sp.speaker: SCAPHA
sp.p: A woman who neglects herself and her youthful age has occasion for a mirror; what need of a mirror have you, who yourself are in especial a mirror for a mirror.

p.#text: . For that expression, Scapha, that you mayn't have said anything so pretty in vain, I'll to-day give something for your savings--to you, my Philematium.

p.stage: while SCAPHA is dressing her hair
p.#text: . Will you see that each hair is nicely arranged in its own place?

sp.speaker: SCAPHA
sp.p: When you yourself are so nice, do believe that your hair must be nice.

p.#text: . Out upon it! what worse thing can possibly be spoken of than this woman? Now the jade's a flatterer, just now she was all contradictory.

note.#text: :  White lead, or "cerussa," was used by the Roman women for the purpose of whitening the complexion. Ovid mentions it in his Treatise on the Care of the Complexion, l. 73.

p.#text: Hand me the ceruse.

sp.speaker: SCAPHA
sp.p: Why, what need of ceruse have you?

sp.speaker: PHILEMATIUM
sp.p: To paint my cheeks with it.

sp.speaker: SEA.
sp.p: On the same principle, you would want to be making ivory white with ink.

p.#text: . Cleverly said that, about the ink and the ivory! Bravo! I applaud you, Scapha.

sp.speaker: PHILEMATIUM
sp.p: Well then, do you give me the rouge.

p.#text: I shan't give it. You really are a clever one. Do you wish to patch up a most clever piece with new daubing? It's not right that any paint should touch that person, neither ceruse, nor quince-ointment, nor any other wash. Take the mirror, then.
Ah wretched me!--she gave the glass a kiss. I could much wish for a stone, with which to break the head of that glass.

sp.speaker: SCAPHA
sp.p: Take the towel and wipe your hands.

sp.speaker: PHILEMATIUM
sp.p: Why so, prithee?

sp.speaker: SCAPHA
sp.p: As you've been holding the mirror, I'm afraid that your hands may smell of silver; lest Philolaches should suspect you've been receiving silver somewhere.

p.#text: . I don't think that I ever did see any one procuress more cunning. How cleverly and artfully did it occur to the jade's imagination about the mirror!

sp.speaker: PHILEMATIUM
sp.p: Do you think I ought to be perfumed with unguents as well?

sp.speaker: SCAPHA
sp.p: By no means do so.

sp.speaker: PHILEMATIUM
sp.p: For what reason?

note.#text: :  Cicero and Martial have a similar sentiment; their opinion has been followed by many modern writers and other persons as well.

p.#text: Because, i' faith, a woman smells best when she smells of nothing at all. For those old women who are in the habit of anointing themselves with unguents, vampt up creatures, old hags, and toothless, who hide the blemishes of the person with paint, when the sweat has blended itself with the unguents, forthwith they stink just like when a cook has poured together a variety of broths; what they smell of, you don't know, except this only, that you understand that badly they do smell.

. How very cleverly she does understand everything! There's nothing more knowing than this knowing woman!  This is the truth, and a very great portion, in fact, of you know it, who have old women for wives at home who purchased you with their portions.

sp.speaker: PHITE.
sp.p: Come now, examine my golden trinkets and my mantle; does this quite become me, Scapha?

sp.speaker: SCAPHA
sp.p: It befits not me to concern myself about that.

sp.speaker: PHILEMATIUM
sp.p: Whom then, prithee?

sp.speaker: SCAPHA
sp.p: I'll tell you; Philolaches; so that he may not buy anything except that which he fancies will please you. For a lover buys the favours of a mistress for himself with gold and purple garments. What need is there for that which he doesn't want as his own, to be shown him still? Age is to be enveloped in purple; gold ornaments are unsuitable for a woman. A beautiful woman will be more beautiful naked than drest in purple. Besides, it's in vain she's well-drest if she's ill-conducted; ill-conduct soils fine ornaments worse than dirt. But if she's beauteous, she's sufficiently adorned.

p.#text: . Too long have I withheld my hand.  What are you about here?

sp.speaker: PHILEMATIUM
sp.p: I'm decking myself out to please you.

p.#text: You are dressed enough.  Go you hence in-doors, and take away this finery.  But, my delight, my Philematium, I have a mind to regale together with you.

sp.speaker: PHILEMATIUM
sp.p: And, i' faith, so I have with you; for what you have a mind to, the same have I a mind to, my delight.

sp.speaker: PHILOLACHES
sp.p: Ha! at twenty mine that expression were cheap.

sp.speaker: PHILEMATIUM
sp.p: Give me ten, there's a dear; I wish to let you have that expression bought a bargain.

sp.speaker: PHILOLACHES
sp.p: You've already got ten min with you; or reckon up the account: thirty min I gave for your freedom----

sp.speaker: PHILEMATIUM
sp.p: Why reproach me with that?

sp.speaker: PHILOLACHES
sp.p: What, I reproach you with it? Why, I had rather that I myself were reproached with it; no money whatever for this long time have I ever laid out equally well.

sp.speaker: PHILEMATIUM
sp.p: Surely, in loving you, I never could have better employed my pains.

sp.speaker: PHILOLACHES
sp.p: The account, then, of receipts and expenditure fully tallies between ourselves; you love me, I love you. Each thinks that it is so deservedly. Those who rejoice at this, may they ever rejoice at the continuance of their own happiness. Those who envy, let not any one henceforth be ever envious of their blessings.

stage: pointing to a couch on the stage
At the door, to a SERVANT, who obeys.
p.#text: . Come, take your place, then.  Boy, bring some water for the hands; put a little table here. See where are the dice. Would you like some perfumes?

sp.speaker: PHILOLACHES
sp.p: What need is there? Along with myrrh I am reclining. But isn't this my friend who's coming hither with his mistress? 'Tis he; it's Callidamates; look, he's coming. Capital! my sweet one, see, our comrades are approaching; they're coming to share the spoil.

div2.stage: Enter CALLIDAMATES, at a distance, drunk, and DELPHIUIM, followed by a SERVANT.

note.#text: :  Though none of the Editions say so, it is not improbable that this is said to Phaniscus, who, in the sequel, comes to fetch Callidamates home. The duties of the "adversitor" have been alluded to in a previous Note.

p.#text: . I want you to come for me in good time to the house of Philolaches; listen you; well then! those are your orders.  For from the place where I was, thence did I betake myself off;> so confoundedly tired was I there. with the entertainment and the discourse. Now I'll go to Philolaches to have a bout there he'll receive us with jovial feelings and handsomely. Do I seem to you to be fairly drenched, my bubsy?

sp.speaker: DELPHIUM
sp.p: You ought always to live pursuing this course of life.

sp.speaker: CALLIDAMATES
sp.p: Should you like, then, for me to hug you, and you me?

sp.speaker: DELPHIUM
sp.p: If you've a mind to do so, of course.

p.#text: You are a charming one.  Do hold me up, there's a dear.
. Take care you don't fall. Stand up.
O! you are the apple of my eye. I'm your fosterling, my honey.
. Only do take care that you don't recline in the street, before we get to a place where a couch is ready laid.

sp.speaker: CALLIDAMATES
sp.p: Do let me fall.

p.#text: Well, I'll let you.
. But that as well which I've got hold of in my hand.
If you fall, you shan't fall without me falling with you. Then some one shall pick us both up as we lie  The man's quite drenched.
. Do you say that I am drenched, my bubsy?

sp.speaker: DELPHIUM
sp.p: Give me your hand; I really do not want * * you hurt.

p.#text: . There now, take it.

sp.speaker: DELPHIUM
sp.p: Come, move on with me.

sp.speaker: CALLIDAMATES
sp.p: Where am I going, do you know?

sp.speaker: DELPHIUM
sp.p: I know.

sp.speaker: CALLIDAMATES
sp.p: It has just come into my head: why, of course I'm going home for a booze.

sp.speaker: DELPHIUM
sp.p: Why yes, really now I do remember that.

p.#text: Won't you let me go to find them, my life? Of all persons I wish well to him especially. I'll return just now.

sp.speaker: PHILEMATIUM
sp.p: That "just now" is a long time to me.

p.stage: going to the door and knocking
p.#text: . Is there any person here?

sp.speaker: PHILOLACHES
sp.p: 'Tis he.

p.#text: . Bravo! Philolaches, good day to you, most friendly to me of all men.
May the Gods bless you.  Take your place, Callidamates.  Whence are you betaking yourself?

sp.speaker: CALLIDAMATES
sp.p: Whence a drunken man does.

p.stage: She takes her place on a couch.
p.#text: Well said. But, my Delphium, do take your place, there's a dear.
Give her something to drink. I shall go to sleep directly.

sp.speaker: PHILOLACHES
sp.p: He doesn't do anything wonderful or strange. What shall I do with him then, my dear?

sp.speaker: DELPHIUM
sp.p: Let him alone just as he is.

sp.speaker: PHILOLACHES
sp.p: Come, you boy. Meanwhile, speedily pass the goblet round, beginning with Delphium.

note.#text: :  See the Captivi, l. 535, and the Note to the passage.
: -- "Fal" were wooden towers, placed on the top of walls or fortified places; of course the attack of these would imply extreme danger to those who attempted it.

lemma.#text: Twice his feet, twice his arms

note.#text: :  Some suppose that by "bis pedes, bis brachia," he means that two nails were to be driven into each leg and foot. It seems more probable that he means two for the feet and two for the hands.

p.#text: . Supreme Jove, with all his might and resources, is seeking for me and Philolaches, my master's son, to be undone. Our hopes are destroyed; nowhere is there any hold for courage; not even Salvation now could save us if she wished. Such an immense mountain of woe have I just now seen at the harbour: my master has arrived from abroad; Tranio is undone!  Is there any person who'd like to make gain of a little money, who could this day endure to take my place in being tortured? Where are those fellows hardened to a flogging, the wearers- out of iron chains, or those, who, for the consideration of three didrachms, would get beneath besieging towers, where some are in the way of having their bodies pierced with fifteen spears? I'll give a talent to that man who shall be the first to run to the cross for me; but on condition that twice his feet, twice his arms are fastened there. When that shall have been done, then ask the money down of me. But am I not a wretched fellow, not at full speed to be running home?

sp.speaker: PHILOLACHES
sp.p: Here come the provisions; see, here's Tranio; he's come back from the harbour.

p.#text: . Philolaches!

sp.speaker: PHILOLACHES
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Both I and you----

sp.speaker: PHILOLACHES
sp.p: What about "Both I and you?"

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Are undone!

sp.speaker: PHILOLACHES
sp.p: Why so?

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Your father's here.

sp.speaker: PHILOLACHES
sp.p: What is it I hear of you?

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: We are finished up. Your father's come, I say.

p.#text: Where is he, I do entreat you?

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: He's coming.

sp.speaker: PHILOLACHES
sp.p: Coming? Who says so? Who has seen him?

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: I saw him myself, I tell you.

sp.speaker: PHILOLACHES
sp.p: Woe unto me! what am I about?

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Why the plague now do you ask me what you are about? Taking your place at table, of course.

sp.speaker: PHILOLACHES
sp.p: Did you see him?

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: I my own self, I tell you.

sp.speaker: PHILOLACHES
sp.p: For certain?

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: For certain, I tell you.

sp.speaker: PHILOLACHES
sp.p: I'm undone, if you are telling the truth.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: What good could it be to me if I told a lie?

sp.speaker: PHILOLACHES
sp.p: What shall I do now?

stage: pointing to the table and couches
p.#text: . Order all these things to be removed from here.  Who's that asleep there?

sp.speaker: PHILOLACHES
sp.p: Callidamates.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Arouse him, Delphium.

p.#text: . Callidamates! Callidamates! awake! CALL. . I am awake; give me something to drink.

sp.speaker: DELPHIUM
sp.p: Awake; the father of Philolaches has arrived from abroad.

sp.speaker: CALLIDAMATES
sp.p: I hope his father's well.

sp.speaker: PHILOLACHES
sp.p: He is well indeed; but I am utterly undone.

sp.speaker: CALLIDAMATES
sp.p: You, utterly undone? How can that be?

sp.speaker: PHILOLACHES
sp.p: By heavens! do get up, I beg of you; my father has arrived.

sp.speaker: CALLIDAMATES
sp.p: Your father has come? Bid him go back again. What business had he to come back here so soon?

sp.speaker: PHILOLACHES
sp.p: What am I to do? My father will, just now, be coming and unfortunately finding me amid drunken carousals, and the house full of revellers and women. It's a shocking bad job, to be digging a well at the last moment, just when thirst has gained possession of your throat; just as I, on the arrival of my father, wretch that I am, am now enquiring what I am to do.

p.#text: . Why look, he has laid down his head and gone to sleep. Do arouse him.
. Will you awake now? My father, I tell you, will be here this instant.

sp.speaker: CALLIDAMATES
sp.p: How say you? Your father? Give me my shoes, that I may take up arms. On my word, I'll kill your father this instant.

p.#text: . You're spoiling the whole business; do hold your tongue.  Prithee, do carry him off in your arms into the house.

stage: To DELPHIUM, who is lifting him up
He is led off into the house.
p.#text: . Upon my faith, I'll be making an utensil of you just now, if you don't find me one.

sp.speaker: PHILOLACHES
sp.p: I'm undone!

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Be of good courage; I'll cleverly find a remedy for this alarm.

sp.speaker: PHILOLACHES
sp.p: I'm utterly ruined!

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Do hold your tongue; I'll think of something by means of which to alleviate this for you. Are you satisfied, if on his arrival I shall so manage your father, not only that he shall not enter, but even that he shall run away to a distance from the house? Do you only be off from here in-doors, and remove these things from here with all haste.

sp.speaker: PHILOLACHES
sp.p: Where am I to be?

p.#text: Where you especially desire: with her ; with this girl, too, you'll be.

sp.speaker: DELPHIUM
sp.p: How then? Are we to go away from here?

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Not far from here, Delphium. For carouse away in the house not a bit the less on account of this.

sp.speaker: PHILOLACHES
sp.p: Ah me! I'm in a sweat with fear as to how these fine words are to end!

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Can you not be tranquil in your mind, and do as I bid you?

sp.speaker: PHILOLACHES
sp.p: I can be.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: In the first place of all, Philematium, do you go in-doors; and you, Delphium.

p.#text: We'll both be obedient to you.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: May Jupiter grant it so! Now then, do you give attention as to what I'd have attended to. In the first place, then, before anything, cause the house to be shut up at once. Take care and don't let any one whisper a word indoors.

sp.speaker: PHILOLACHES
sp.p: Care shall be taken.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Just as though no living being were dwelling within the house.

sp.speaker: PHILOLACHES
sp.p: Very well.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: And let no one answer, when the old gentleman knocks at the door.

sp.speaker: PHILOLACHES
sp.p: Anything else?

note.#text: :  "Clavem--Laconicam;" literally, "the Laconian key." This was a kind of key originally invented by the Spartans, by means of which a door could be locked from the outside, but not from within. According to some, this key was called "Laconica," from its rough appearance, in allusion to the inelegant exterior of the Spartans. In his Thesmophoriazus, Aristophanes informs us that these keys had three wards.

p.#text: Order the master-key of the house to be brought me at once from within; this house I'll lock here on the outside.

p.stage: He goes into the house, and the things are removed from the stage.
p.#text: To your charge I commit myself, Tranio, and my hopes.

stage: Enter a BOY, from the house.
p.#text: . It matters not a feather whether a patron or a dependant is the nearest at hand for that man who has got no courage in his breast. For to every man, whether very good or very bad, even at a moment's notice, it is easy to act with craft; but this must be looked to, this is the duty of a prudent man, that what has been planned and done in craftiness, may all come about smoothly and without mishap; so that he may not have to put up with anything by reason of which he might be loth to live; just as I shall manage, that, from the confusion which we shall here create, all shall really go on smoothly and tranquilly, and not produce us any inconvenience in the results.  But, why have you come out? I'm undone! (The

sp.speaker: A BOY.
sp.p: shows him the key.) O very well, you've obeyed my orders most opportunely.

sp.speaker: A BOY.
sp.p: He bade me most earnestly to entreat you some way or other to scare away his father, that he may not enter the house.

note.#text: :  With the ancients, when either ashamed or alarmed at anything, it was the custom to throw a part of the dress over the head, as a hood.
: , He plays on the double meaning of "ludos," which means either "tricks," or "funerai games" in honor of the dead, according to the context.

stage: The BOY goes into the house, and TRANIO locks the door.
p.#text: Even more, tell him this, that I'll cause that he shan't venture even to look at the house, and to take to flight, covering up his head with the greatest alarm. Give me the key , and be off in-doors, and shut to the door, and I'll lock it on this side.  Bid him now come forthwith. For the old gentleman here while still alive this day will I institute games in his presence, such as I fancy there will never be for him when he's dead.  I'll go away from the door to this spot; hence, I'll look out afar in which direction to lay the burden on the old fellow on his arrival.

. Neptune, I do return extreme thanks to thee that thou hast just dismissed me from thee, though scarce alive. But if, from this time forward, thou shalt only know that I have stirred a foot upon the main, there is no reason why, that instant, thou shouldst not do with me that which thou hast now wished to do. Away with you, away with you from me henceforth for ever after to-day; what I was to entrust to thee, all of it have I now entrusted.
. By my troth, Neptune, you've been much to blame, to have lost this opportunity so fair.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: After three years, I've arrived home from gypt. I shall come a welcome guest to my household, I suppose.

p.#text: . Upon my faith, he might have come a much more welcome one, who had brought the tidings you were dead.
. But what means this? Is the door shut in the daytime? I'll knock.  Hallo, there! is any one going to open this door for me?
. What person is it that has come so near to our house?

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: Surely this is my servant Tranio.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: O Theuropides, my master, welcome; I'm glad that you've arrived in safety.

sp.speaker: HAVE
sp.p: you been well all along?

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: All along, as you see.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: That's very good.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: What about yourselves? Are you all mad?

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Why so?

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: For this reason; because you are walking about outside; not a born person is keeping watch in the house, either to open or to give an answer. With kicking with my feet I've almost broken in the pannels?

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: How now? Have you been touching this house?

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: Why shouldn't I touch it? Why, with kicking it, I tell you, I've almost broken down the door.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: What, you touched it?

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: I touched it, I tell you, and knocked at it.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Out upon you!

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: Why so?

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: By heavens! 'twas ill done.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: What is the matter?

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: It cannot be expressed, how shocking and dreadful a mischief you've been guilty of.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: How so?

p.#text: Take to flight, I beseech you, and get away from the house. Fly in this direction, fly closer to me.  What, did you touch the door?

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: How could I knock, if I didn't touch it?

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: By all that's holy, you've been the death----

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: Of what person?

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Of all your family.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: May the Gods and Goddesses confound you with that omen.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: I'm afraid that you can't make satisfaction for yourself and them.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: For what reason, or what new affair is this that you thus suddenly bring me news of?

stage: Pointing to the ATTENDANTS of THEUROPIDES.
p.#text: And  hark you, prithee, do bid those people to move away from here.
. Move away from here.

note.#text: :  The ancients were in the habit of reverentially touching the earth, when engaged in any affairs that related to the dead or the infernal Deities.

p.#text: Don't you touch the house. Touch you the ground as well.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: I' faith, prithee, do speak out now.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Because it is now seven months that not a person has set foot within this house, and since we once for all left it.

sp.speaker: THEE.
sp.p: Tell me, why so?

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Just look around, whether there's any person to overhear our discourse.

p.#text: . All's quite safe.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Look around once more.

note.#text: :  'Capitalis des facta eat;" meaning that a murder had been committed in it.

p.#text: . There's nobody; now then, speak out. TRA. . The house has been guilty of a capital offence.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: I don't understand you.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: A crime, I tell you, has been committed there, a long while ago, one of olden time and ancient date.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: Of ancient date?

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: 'Tis but recently, in fact, that we've discovered this deed.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: What is this crime, or who committed it? Tell me.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: A host slew his guest, seized with his hand; he, I fancy, who sold you the house.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: Slew him?

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: And robbed this guest of his gold, and buried this guest there in the house, on the spot.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: For what reason do you suspect that this took place?

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: I'll tell you; listen. One day, when your son had dined away from home, after he returned home from dining; we all went to bed, and fell asleep. By accident, I had forgotten to put out my lamp; and he, all of a sudden, called out aloud----

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: What person? My son?

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Hist! hold your peace: just listen. He said that a dead man came to him in his sleep----

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: In his dreams, then, you mean?

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Just so. But only listen. He said that he had met with his death by these means----

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: What, in his sleep?

p.#text: It would have been surprising if he had told him awake, who had been murdered sixty years ago. On some occasions you are absurdly simple. But look, what he said: "I am the guest of Diapontius, from beyond the seas; here do I dwell; this has been assigned me as my abode; for Orcus would not receive me in Acheron, because prematurely I lost my life. Through confiding was I deceived: my entertainer slew me here, and that villain secretly laid me in the ground without funereal rites, in this house, on the spot, for the sake of gold. Now do you depart from here; this house is accursed, this dwelling is defiled." The wonders that here take place, hardly in a year could I recount them. Hush, hush!

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: Troth now, what has happened, prithee?

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: The door made a noise. Was it he that was knocking?

p.#text: . I have not one drop of blood! Dead men are come to fetch me to Acheron, while alive!

stage: A noise is heard from within.
p.#text: . I'm undone! those people there will mar my plot.  How much I dread, lest he should catch me in the fact.
What are you talking about to yourself?

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Do get away from the door. By heavens, fly, I do beseech you.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: Fly where? Fly yourself, as well.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: I am not afraid: I am at peace with the dead.

note.#text: :  Weise's Edition gives these words to Theuropides, Rost, no doubt rightly, suggests that these words are spoken by Philolaches from inside (perhaps in a low voice, to ask Tranio how matters are going on). On this, Tranio turns it to good account, by pretending that the Ghost is calling out to him for his supposed impiety in daring to knock at the door.

p.#text: . Hallo! Tranio.

stage: in a low voice, near the door
Aloud, as if speaking to the APPARITION.
p.#text: . You won't be calling me, if you are wise.  'Tis not I that's guilty; I did not knock at the door.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: Pray, what is it that's wrong? What matter is agitating you, Tranio? To whom are you saying these things?

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Prithee, was it you that called me? So may the Gods bless me, I fancied it was this dead man expostulating because you had knocked at the door. But are you still standing there, and not doing what I advise you?

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: What am I to do?

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Take care not to look back. Fly; cover up your head!

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: Why don't you fly?

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: I am at peace with the dead.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: I recollect. Why then were you so dreadfully alarmed just now?

note.#text: :  Hercules having slain so many monsters, was naturally regarded as a Deity likely to give aid in extreme danger.

p.#text: Have no care for me, I tell you; I'll see to myself. You, as you have begun to do, fly as quick as ever you can; Hercules, too, you will invoke.
Hercules, I do invoke thee!
And I, as well, old fellow, that; this day he'll send some heavy mishap upon you. O ye immortal Gods, I do implore your aid. Plague on it! what a mess I have got into to-day.

div2.stage: Enter a BANKER, at the end of the stage.

p.#text: . I never knew any year worse for money upon interest, than this year has turned out to me. From morning even until night, I spend my time in the Forum; I cannot lend out a coin of silver to any one.

. Now, faith, I am clearly undone in an everlasting way! The Banker's here who found the money with which his mistress was bought. The matter's all out, unless I meet him a bit beforehand, so that the old man may not at present come to know of this. I'll go meet him. But  I wonder why he has so soon betaken himself homeward again. I'm afraid that he has heard something about this affair. I'll meet him, and accost him. But how dreadfully frightened I am! Nothing is more wretched than the mind of a man with a guilty conscience, such as possesses myself. But however this matter turns out, I'll proceed to perplex it still further: so does this affair require.
. Whence come you?

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: I met that person from whom I bought this house.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Did you tell him anything about that which I was telling you?

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: I' faith, I certainly told him everything.

p.#text: . Woe to unfortunate me! I'm afraid that my schemes are everlastingly undone!

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: What is it you are saying to yourself?

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Why nothing. But tell me, prithee, did you really tell him?

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: I told him everything in its order, I tell you.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Does he, then, confess about the guest?

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: Why no; he utterly denies it.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Does he deny it?

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: Do you ask me again? I should tell you if he had confessed it. What now are you of opinion ought to be done?

lemma.#text: As a fox eats a pear

note.#text: :  This may either mean, very easily indeed, or not at all. It is not clear that a fox will eat a pear; but if he does, his teeth will go through it with the greatest ease. Not improbably, Tranio uses the expression for its ambiguity.

p.#text: What is my opinion? By my troth, I beg of you, appoint an arbitrator together with him; but take you care that you appoint one who will believe me; you'll overcome him as easily as a fox eats a pear.

stage: Goes towards TRANIO, who steps forward to meet him.
p.#text: . But see, here's Tranio, the servant of Philolaches, people who pay me neither interest nor principal on my money.
. Whither are you betaking yourself?

I'm going no whither.  For sure, I am a wretch, a rascal, one born with all the Gods my foes! He'll now be accosting me in the old man's presence. Assuredly, I am a wretched man; in such a fashion both this way and that do they find business for me. But I'll make haste and accost him.
. He's coming towards me. I'm all right I've some hopes of my money; he's smiling.

note.#text: :  A nickname coined by the author, from "satur," "brimful," of money, probably.

p.#text: . The fellow's deceived.  I heartily bid you hail, my friend Saturides.

sp.speaker: A BANKER.
sp.p: And hail to you. What about the money?

note.#text: :  "Pilum injecisti." Literally, "you have thrown the dart." " To throw the dart" was a common expression, signifying "to make the first attack;" as the darts were thrown before recourse was had

p.#text: Be off with you, will you, you brute. Directly you come, you commence the attack against me.
. This fellow's empty-handed.
. This fellow's surely a conjurer.

sp.speaker: A BANKER.
sp.p: But why don't you put an end to this trifling?

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Tell me, then, what it is you want.

sp.speaker: A BANKER.
sp.p: Where is Philolaches?

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: You never could have met me more opportunely than you have met me.

sp.speaker: A BANKER.
sp.p: How's that?

p.#text: . Step this way.
. Why isn't the money repaid me?

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: I know that you have a good voice; don't bawl out so loud.

p.#text: . I' faith, I certainly shall bawl out.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: O do humour me now.

sp.speaker: A BANKER.
sp.p: What do you want me to humour you in?

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Prithee, be off hence home.

sp.speaker: A BANKER.
sp.p: Be off?

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Return here about mid-day.

sp.speaker: A BANKER.
sp.p: Will the interest be paid then?

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: It will be paid. Be off.

sp.speaker: A BANKER.
sp.p: Why should I run to and fro here, or use or waste my pains? What if I remain here until mid-day in preference?

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Why no; be off home. On my word, I'm telling the truth. Only do be off.

p.#text: . Then do you pay me my interest. Why do you trifle with me this way?

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Bravo! faith. Really now, do be off; do attend to me.

p.#text: . I' faith, I'll call him now by name.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Bravo! stoutly done! Really you are quite rich now when you bawl out.

note.#text: :  By "hoc verbum" he probably alludes to the expression, "reddite argentum, "down with the money."

p.#text: . I'm asking for my own. In this way you've been disappointing me for these many days past. If I'm troublesome, give me back the money; I'll go away then. That expression puts an end to all replies.

note.#text: :  He finds he must say something, so he says this, although he has no money with him. He knows, however, that the usurer will first insist on the interest being paid, because if he takes the principal, it will be a legal waver of his right to claim the interest.

p.#text: . Then, take the principal.
. Why no, the interest; I want that first.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: What? Have you, you fellow most foul of all fellows, come here to burst yourself? Do what lies in your power. He's not going to pay you; he doesn't owe it.

sp.speaker: A BANKER.
sp.p: Not owe it?

note.#text: :  "Quin sortem potius dare licet?" is the reading here, in Weise's Edition; but the line seems hopelessly incorrect.

p.#text: Not a tittle, indeed, can you get from here. Would you prefer for him to go abroad, and leave the city in exile, driven hence for your sake? Why then, in preference let him pay the principal.

sp.speaker: A BANKER.
sp.p: But I don't ask for it.

p.stage: calling out to TRANIO, from a distance
p.#text: . Hark you! you whip-knave, come back to me.
. I'll be there just now.  Don't you be troublesome: no one's going to pay you; do what you please. You are the only person, I suppose, that lends money upon interest.
. Give me my interest! pay me my interest! you pay my interest! Are you going to give me my interest this instant? Give me my interest!

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Interest here, interest there! The old rogue knows how to talk about nothing but interest. I do not think that ever I saw any beast more vile than you.

note.#text: :  This line is given by Gruter to Theuropides, by Acidalius to Tranio, and by Lambinus to the Banker. The latter seems the most appropriate owner of it; and he probably alludes, aside, to the effects of his pressing in a loud voice for the money. Tranio is introduced as using the same expression, in l. 650; but there can be no doubt that the line, as there inserted, is spurious.

p.#text: Upon my faith, you don't alarm me now with those expressions. This is of a hot nature; although it is at a distance off, it scorches badly.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Don't you be troublesome; no one's going to pay you; do what you please. You are the only person, I suppose, that lends money upon interest.

p.#text: . Pray, what interest is this that he is asking for?

p.stage: in a low voice, to the BANKER
p.#text: . Look now; his father has arrived from abroad, not long since; he'll pay you both interest and principal; don't you then attempt any further to make us your enemies. See whether he puts you off.

sp.speaker: A BANKER.
sp.p: Nay but, I'll take it, if anything's offered.

p.#text: . What do you say, then----?

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: What is it you mean?

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: Who is this? What is he asking for? Why is he thus rudely speaking of my son Philolaches in this way, and giving you abuse to your face? What's owing him?

p.#text: . I beg of you, do order the money to be thrown in the face of this dirty brute.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: I, order it?

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Order the fellow's face to be pelted with money.

p.#text: . I could very well put up with a pelting with money.
. What money's this?

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Philolaches owes this person a little.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: How much?

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: About forty min.

p.#text: . Really, don't think much of that; it's a trifle, in fact.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Don't you hear him? Troth now, prithee, doesn't he seem just suited to be a Banker--a generation that's most roguish?

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: I don't care, just now, for that, who he is or whence he is; this I want to be told me, this I very much wish to know--I heard from him that there was interest owing on the money as well.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Forty-four min are due to him. Say that you'll pay it, that he may be off.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: I, say that I'll pay it?

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Do say so.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: What, I?

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: You yourself. Do only say so. Do be guided by me. Do promise. Come now, I say; I beg of you.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: Answer me; what has been done with this money?

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: It's safe.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: Pay it yourselves then, if it's safe,

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Your son has bought a house.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: A house?

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: A house.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: Bravo! Philolaches is taking after his father! The fellow now turns to merchandize. A house, say you?

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: A house, I tell you. But do you know of what sort?

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: How can I know?

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Out with you!

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Don't ask me that.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: But why so?

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Bright as a mirror, pure brilliancy itself.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: Excellently done, upon my faith! Well, how much did he agree to give for it?

note.#text: :  Warner suggests, that by using this expression before the Banker, he intends to make a secret of the house being haunted, and that he keeps up the mystery in the succeeding line.

p.#text: As many great talents as you and I put together make; but these forty min he paid by way of earnest.  From him he received what we paid the other man. Do you quite understand? For after this house was in such a state as I mentioned to you, he at once purchased another house for himself.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: Excellently done, upon my faith!

p.#text: . Hark you. Mid-day is now close at hand.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Prithee, do dismiss this puking fellow, that he mayn't worry us to death. Forty-four min are due to him, both principal and interest.

sp.speaker: A BANKER.
sp.p: 'Tis just that much; I ask for nothing more.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Upon my faith, I really could have wished that you had asked more, if only by a single coin.

p.#text: . Young man, transact the business with me.

sp.speaker: A BANKER.
sp.p: I'm to ask it of you, you mean?

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: Come for it to-morrow.

p.#text: I'll be off, then; I'm quite satisfied if I get it tomorrow.

. A plague may all the Gods and Goddesses send upon him! so utterly has he disarranged my plans. On my word, no class of men is there more disgusting, or less acquainted with fair dealing than the banking race.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: In what neighbourhood did my son buy this house?

p.#text: . Just see that, now! I'm undone!

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: Are you going to tell me that which I ask you?

p.#text: I'll tell you; but I'm thinking what was the name of the owner.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: Well, call it to mind, then.

p.#text: . What am I to do now, except put the lie upon this neighbour of ours next door? I'll say that his son has bought that house. I' faith, I've heard say that a lie piping-hot is the best lie; this is piping-hot; although it is at a distance off, it scorches badly. Whatever the Gods dictate, that am I determined to say.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: Well now? Have you recollected it by this?

p.#text: . May the Gods confound that fellow!--no this other fellow, rather.  Your son has bought the house of this next-door neighbour of yours.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: In real truth?

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: If, indeed, you are going to pay down the money, then in real truth; if you are not going to pay it, in real truth he has not bought it.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: He hasn't bought it in a very good situation.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Why yes, in a very good one.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: I' faith, I should like to look over this house; just knock at the door, and call some one to you from within, Tranio.

p.#text: . Why just look now, again I don't know what I'm to say. Once more, now, are the surges bearing me upon the self-same rock. What now? I' faith, I can't discover what I am now to do; I'm caught in the fact.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: Just call some one out of doors; ask him to show us round.

stage: going to the door of SIMO'S house
p.#text: . Hallo there, you!  But there are ladies here; we must first see whether they are willing or unwilling.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: You say what's good and proper; just make enquiry, and ask. I'll wait here outside until you come out.

stage: THEUROPIDES and TRANIO stand at a distance from SIMO'S house, in opposite directions, THEUROPIDES being out of sight.
p.#text: . May all the Gods and Goddesses utterly confound you, old gentleman! in such a fashion are you thwarting my artful plans in every way. Bravo! very good! Look, Simo himself, the owner of the house, is coming out of doors. I'll step aside here, until I have convened the senate of council in my mind. Then, when I've discovered what I am to do, I'll join him.

note.#text: :  It was a custom with the Romans to take a nap at noon, after the "prandium." The modern Italians have the same practice, and call it the "siesta." Simo has his private reasons for thinking that this nap is not wholesome in his own case.

p.#text: . I've not enjoyed myself better at home this year than I have to-day, nor has at any time any meal pleased me better. My wife provided a very nice breakfast for me; now she bids me go take a nap. By no means! It instantly struck me that it didn't so happen by chance. She provided a better breakfast than is her wont; and then, the old lady wanted to draw me away to my chamber. Sleep is not good after breakfast--out upon it! I secretly stole away from the house, out of doors. My wife, I'm sure, is now quite bursting with rage at home.
. A sore mischance is provided for this old fellow by the evening; for he must both dine and go to bed in-doors in sorry fashion.

. The more I reflect upon it in my mind: if any person has a dowried wife, sleep has no charms for him. I detest going to take a nap. It's a settled matter with me to be off to the Forum from here, rather than nap it at home. And, i' faith , I don't know how your wives are in their behaviour; this wife of mine, I know right well how badly she treats me, and that she will prove more annoying to me hereafter than she has been.

note.#text: :  "Hoc habet." Literally, "he has it;" a term used by the Spectators, when a gladiator received a wound at the gladiatorial games.

lemma.#text: By means of which to drive grief

note.#text: :  He plays upon the resemblance of the words "dolo" and "dolorem."

p.#text: . If your escape, old gentleman, turns out amiss, there'll be no reason for you to be accusing any one of the Gods; by very good right, you may justly lay the blame upon yourself. It's time now for me to accost this old fellow. 'Tis down upon him. I've hit upon a plan whereby to cajole the old fellow, by means of which to drive grief away from me. I'll accost him.  May the Gods, Simo, send on you many blessings!

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: Save you, Tranio!

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: How fare you?

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: Not amiss. What are you about?

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Holding by the hand a very worthy man.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: You act in a friendly way, in speaking well of me.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: It certainly is your due.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: But, i' faith, in you I don't hold a good servant by the hand.

p.stage: calling from a distance, where he is not perceived by SIMO
p.#text: . Hark you! you whip-knave, come back to me.
. I'll be there just now.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: Well now, how soon----?

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: What is it?

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: The usual goings-on.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Tell me then, these usual goings-on, what are they?

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: The way that you yourselves proceed. But, Tranio, to say the truth, according as men are, it so befits you to humour them; reflecting, at the same time, how short life is.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: What of all this? Dear me, at last, after some difficulty, I perceive that you are talking about these goings-on of ours.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: I' faith, you people are living a merry life, just as befits you: on wine, good cheer, nice dainty fish, you enjoy life.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Why yes, so it was in time past, indeed; but now these things have come to an end all at once.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: So utterly, Simo, are we all undone!

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: Won't you hold your tongue? Everything has gone on prosperously with you hitherto.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: I don't deny that it has been as you say; undoubtedly, we have lived heartily, just as we pleased; but, Simo, in such a way has the breeze now forsaken our ship----

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: What's the matter? In what way?

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: In a most shocking way.

note.#text: :  It was the custom, when ships were not in use, especially in the winter time, to draw them up on shore, by means of rollers placed beneath them.

p.#text: What, wasn't it hauled ashorein safety?

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Ah me!

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Ah wretched me! I'm utterly undone!

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Because a ship has come, to smash the hull of our ship.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: I would wish as you would wish, Tranio, for your own sake. But what is the matter? Do inform me.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: I will inform you. My master has arrived from abroad.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: In that case, the cord will be stretched for you; thence to the place where iron fetters clink; after that, straight to the cross.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Now, by your knees, I do implore you, don't give information to my master.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: Don't you fear; he shall know nothing from me.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Blessings on you, my patron.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: I don't care for clients of this description for myself.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Now as to this about which our old gentleman has sent me.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: First answer me this that I ask you. As yet, has your old gentleman discovered anything of these matters?

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Nothing whatever.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: Has he censured his son at all?

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: He is as calm as the calm weather is wont to be. Now he has requested me most earnestly to beg this of you, that leave may be given him to see over this house of yours.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: It's not for sale.

note.#text: :  "Gynceum." This was a name borrowed from the Greeks, for the apartments in the house which were especially devoted to the use of the females.

p.#text: I know that indeed; but the old gentleman wishes to build a woman's apartment here in his own house, baths, too, and a piazza, and a porch.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: What has he been dreaming of?

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: I'll tell you. He wishes to give his son a wife as soon as he can; for that purpose he wants a new apartment for the women. But he says that some builder, I don't know who, has been praising up to him this house of yours, as being remarkably well built; now he's desirous to take a model from it, if you don't make any objection----

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: Indeed, he is really choosing a plan for himself from a piece of poor workmanship.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: It was because he heard that here the summer heat was much modified; that this house was wont to be inhabited each day all day long.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: Why really, upon my faith, on the contrary, while there's shade in every direction, in spite of it, the sun is always here from morning till night: he stands, like a dun, continually at the door; and I have no shade anywhere, unless, perhaps, there may be some in the well.

note.#text: :  This is a poor pun upon the different acceptations of the word "umbra," which may signify, according to the context, "shade," or "a woman of Umbria." Simo means it in the former, while Tranio chooses to take it in the latter sense. Simo does not like this attempt at wit, and tells him not to be impertinent. We may here observe, that Plautus was born at Sarsina, a town of Umbria.

p.#text: Well now, have you one from Sarsina, if you have no woman of Umbria?

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: Don't be impertinent. It is just as I tell you.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Still, he wishes to look over it.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: He may look over it, if he likes. If there is anything that takes his fancy, let him build after my plan.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Am I to go and call this person hither?

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: Go and call him.

stage: (to himself, as he goes to the other side of the stage to call THEUROPIDES).

note.#text: :  Agathocles rose from the station of a potter to be king of Sicily.

p.#text: They say that Alexander the Great and Agathocles achieved two very great exploits; what shall be the lot of myself, a third, who, unaided, am achieving deeds imperishable? This old fellow is carrying his pack-saddle, the other one, as well. I've hit upon a novel trade for myself, not a bad one; whereas muleteers have mules to carry pack-saddles; I've got men to carry the pack-saddles. They are able to carry heavy burdens; whatever you put upon them, they carry. Now, I don't know whether I am to address him. I'll accost him, however.  Hark you, Theuropides!
. Well; who's calling me?

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: A servant most attached to his master. Where you sent me, I got it all agreed to.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: Prithee, why did you stay there so long?

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: The old gentleman hadn't leisure; I was waiting until then.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: You keep up that old way of yours, of being tardy.

note.#text: :  Or "exhale and inhale." A proverbial expression, very similar to that in use with us, that "a person cannot blow hot and cold at the same time."

p.#text: Hark you! if you please reflect upon this proverb: to blow and swallow at the same moment isn't easy to be done; I couldn't be here and there at the same time.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: What now?

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Come and look, and inspect it at your own pleasure.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: Very well, you go before me.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Am I delaying to do so?

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: I'll follow after you.

p.#text: . Look, the old gentleman himself is awaiting you before the door, but he is concerned that he has sold this house.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: Why so?

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: He begs me to persuade Philolaches to let him off.

note.#text: :  A country proverb, meaning "every one for himself."

p.#text: I don't think he will. Each man reaps on his own farm. If it had been bought dear, we shouldn't have had permission to return it on his hands. Whatever profit there is, it's proper to bring it home. It don't, now-a-days, befit men to be showing compassion.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: I' faith, you are losing time while you are talking. Follow me.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: Be it so.

p.#text: . I'll give you my services.  There's the old gentleman.  Well now, I've brought you this person.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: I'm glad that you've arrived safely from abroad, Theuropides.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: May the Gods bless you.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: Your servant was telling me that you were desirous to look over this house.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: Unless it's inconvenient to you.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: Oh no; quite convenient. Do step in-doors and look over it.

p.#text: . But yet--the ladies----

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: Take you care not to trouble yourself a straw about any lady. Walk in every direction, wherever you like, all over the house just as though it were your own.

p.#text: . "Just as though----?"
. Oh, take care that you don't throw it in his teeth now in his concern, that you have bought it. Don't you see him, how sad a countenance the old gentleman has?
. I see. TRA. . Then don't seem to exult, and to be overmuch delighted; in fact, don't make mention that you've bought it.
. I understand; and I think you've given good advice, and that it shows a humane disposition.  What now?

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: Won't you go in? Look over it at your leisure, just as you like.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: I consider that you are acting civilly and kindly.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: Troth, I wish to do so. Should you like some one to show you over.

lemma.#text: Away with any one to show

note.#text: :  He says this, not liking the mention of the word "perductor," which, beside meaning an "attendant" or "one to escort," signifies a "pander" or "procurer." So in the next line, "perducto" means "to show over" or "to act the procurer"

p.#text: Away with any one to show me over. I don't want him.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: Why? What's the matter?

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: I'll go wrong, rather than any one should show me over.

p.#text: . Don't you see, this vestibule before the house, and the piazza, of what a compass it is?

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: Troth, really handsome!

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Well, look now. what pillars there are, with what strength they are built, and of what a thickness.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: I don't think that I ever saw handsomer pillars.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: I' faith, they were some time since bought by me at such a price!

p.#text: . Don't you hear--"They were once"? He seems hardly able to refrain from tears.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: At what price did you purchase them?

p.#text: I gave three min for the two, besides the carriage,

p.stage: after looking close at them, to TRANIO
p.#text: . Why, upon my word, they are much more unsound than I thought them at first.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Why so?

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: Because, i' faith, the woodworm has split them both from the bottom.

note.#text: :  From the use of the word "pultiphagus," he probably alludes to Carthaginian workmen, who were very skilful at working in wood. In the Pnulus, Hanno the Carthaginian is called "patruus pultiphagonides," "the pulse-eating kinsman." If this is the meaning, it is pretty clear that he is not speaking in praise of the workmanship. Some, however, ever, think that as, in early times, the lower classes at Rome lived upon "puls," "pap" or "pottage," the Scene being at Athens, Roman workmen are alluded to; if so, he may mean to speak in praise of the work, and to say that no bungling artists made the doors. See the Note in p. 355. The joints are said to wink, from the close conjunction of the eyelids in the act of winking.

p.#text: I think they were cut at an improper season; that fault damages them; but even as it is, they are quite good enough, if they are covered with pitch. But it was no foreign pulse-eating artisan did this work. Don't you see the joints in the door?

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: I see them.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Look, how close together they are sleeping.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: Sleeping?

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: That is, how they wink, I intended to say. Are you satisfied?

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: The more I look at each particular, the more it pleases me.

note.#text: :  By the "crow," he means himself; and by the "vultures," the two old men. Simo is probably standing at some distance off; and knowing that his master's sight is not good, he feels that he may deride him with impunity.

:  "Ad me." Theuropides thinks he means, "in my direction;" whereas Tranio really means, "look 'at me' and you will see the crow;" though he does not intend that his master shall take it in that sense.

p.#text: . Don't you see the painting, where one crow is baffling two vultures? The crow stands there; it's pecking at them both in turn. This way, look, prithee, towards me, that yon may be able to see the crow.  Now do you see it?
. For my part, I really see no crow there.
But do you look in that direction, towards yourselves, since you cannot discover the crow, if perchance you may be able to espy the vultures.  Now do you see them?

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: Upon my faith, I don't see them.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: But I can see two vultures.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: To make an end of it with you, I don't see any bird at all painted here.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Well then, I give it up. I excuse you; it is through age you cannot see.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
sp.p: These things which I can see, really they do all please me mightily.

p.#text: . Now, at length, it's worth your while to move further on. THEU. Troth, you give good advice.
. Ho there, boy! take this person round this house and the apartments. But I myself would have shown you round, if I hadn't had business at the Forum.

sp.speaker: THEUROPIDES
